block.p: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast. Opera

''DON GIOVANNI.'' The Berkshire Opera Company has been attracting attention and loyal patrons over the years for the imaginative, well-cast productions it stages at its summer residence, the Koussevitzky Arts Center of Berkshire Community College, a modern and wonderfully intimate theater with excellent sight lines from every seat. Tomorrow night the company presents Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' with what appears to be a strong roster of singers, including Stephen Powell in the title role, Philip Cokorinos as Leporello, Rachel Rosales as Donna Anna and Barbara Shirvis as Donna Elvira. The production is the work of the imaginative director Robin Guarino; Joel Revzen conducts. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Koussevitzky Arts Center, Berkshire Community College, 1350 West Street, Pittsfield, Mass. Tickets: $20 to $60; (413) 443-7400 (Anthony Tommasini).

GLIMMERGLASS OPERA. The lakeside Glimmerglass Opera outside this lovely village offers three of its productions over the weekend. A new ''La Boheme,'' which updates Puccini's opera to World War I, plays tonight at 8 and Sunday at 2 p.m.; Kelley Nassief and Raul Hernandez are Mimi and Rodolfo. At tomorrow's matinee of ''Acis and Galatea,'' Handel's marvelous score and slight drama are given a cheerful treatment and some good singing by Christine Brandes and Dean Elzinga. More difficult to recommend is tomorrow night's ''Salome.'' Elizabeth Byrne and Ned Barth are strong performers, but Leon Major's staging dives dangerously deep into histrionics. Tomorrow at 1:30 and 8 p.m. Alice Busch Theater, on Route 80 eight miles north of Cooperstown. Tickets: $45 to $90; (607) 547-2255 (Bernard Holland).

''MADAMA BUTTERFLY.'' Daniel Beckwith, a quite impressive young conductor who came up through the Metropolitan Opera, has been working fruitfully as a co-director of the enterprising Lake George Opera Festival, which presents productions at the Amphitheater of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Tomorrow night Mr. Beckwith will be on the podium for a performance of Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' with a promising cast headed by the soprano Cynthia Lawrence in the title role and the tenor David Corman as Pinkerton. The bucolic environs are lovely, and lawn seating is available. Tomorrow at 8:15 p.m. Tickets: $17.50 to $37.50; lawn seats, $13; (518) 587-3330 (Tommasini).
Classical Music

BARGEMUSIC. There is no better place in New York City to experience chamber music with the proper intimacy than at the concerts presented by Bargemusic, the rewarding weekly series that takes place on an acoustically ideal and commodious barge in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge. This weekend's performers are especially fine. Tonight and tomorrow night you can hear the pianist Mihae Lee, the hornist William Purvis and the violinist David Kim performing Brahms's popular Horn Trio, as well as works by Schumann and Prokofiev. On Sunday afternoon, the acclaimed flutist Carol Wincenc, the superb cellist Ronald Thomas and the elegant violist Cynthia Phelps are among the performers in a program of Saint-Saens, Debussy and Brahms. Enjoy the music while taking in a spectacular view of Lower Manhattan. Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn. Today and tomorrow at 7:30 p.m.; Sunday at 4 p.m.. Tickets: $27; $25 for the elderly; $15 for students; (718) 624-4061. (Tommasini).

MANHATTAN STRING QUARTET. The Shostakovich string quartets have always been mainstays of this ensemble's repertory. As part of a continuing Shostakovich cycle, Maverick Concerts is devoting its entire concert to the composer, offering the Quartets Nos. 1, 12 and 13. Sunday at 3 p.m. Maverick Concerts, Maverick Road between Routes 28 and 375, West Hurley, N.Y., outside Woodstock. Tickets: $15; $5 for students (914) 679-8217 (Allan Kozinn).

MOSTLY MOZART. The 34th season of this popular festival comes to an end this weekend with a weirdly balanced but potentially interesting program. Before the intermission Gerard Schwarz will lead the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra and the Riverside Choral Society, with Harolyn Blackwell, soprano, and Peter Rose, bass, in selections from Weber's ''Freischutz.'' In the second half of the program, those forces are to be joined by Kristine Jepson, mezzo-soprano, and Anthony Dean Griffey, tenor, for a performance of Mozart's Mass in C minor. There is also a preconcert recital by a period instrument trio -- Mark Kroll, fortepianist, Carol Lieberman, violinist, and Arthur Fiacco, cello -- offering a Beethoven Violin Sonata and Hummel's arrangements of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro'' Overture and Weber's ''Freischutz'' Overture. Tonight and tomorrow night; recital at 7, concert at 8. Tickets: $20 to $40; (212) 721-6500 (Kozinn).

PAULA ROBISON. The flutist Paula Robison and the pianist Jeremy Denk are collaborating on a wide-ranging program at Maverick Concerts tomorrow. Included are some song transcriptions -- Strauss's ''An der Campagna'' and Debussy's ''Chansons de Bilitis,'' among them -- as well as contemporary works by Robert Beaser (his 1982 Variations) and Robert Starer (''Flutemagic,'' a work that had its premiere at Maverick last summer). Manuel de Falla's ''Baetica'' Sonata and Debussy's ''Isle Joyeuse'' give Mr. Denk a few moments in the spotlight as well. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. Maverick Concerts, Maverick Road between Routes 28 and 375, West Hurley, N.Y., just outside Woodstock. Tickets: $15, $5 for students; (914) 679-8217 (Kozinn).

G. DAVID RYALL. Born and trained in Florida, and now organist of the First Presbyterian Church of Pine Bluff, Ark., Mr. Ryall offers two big works: Mendelssohn's Second Sonata and the Suite ''Medievale'' by Jean Langlais, whose mystical-modal and virtuoso style is close to that of the early organ works of his contemporary, Messiaen. Sunday at 4:45 p.m. St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue at 50th Street, Manhattan. Free. (212) 753-2261 (Paul Griffiths).

TANGLEWOOD. The Boston Symphony Orchestra's summer residency at Tanglewood ends this weekend with three concerts that cut a wide swath through the Romantic repertory. Tonight at 8:30, the violinist Joshua Bell plays the Sibelius Concerto on a program otherwise devoted to the Mahler Symphony No. 1. Rafael Frubeck de Burgos conducts. Tomorrow at 8:30 p.m., Andre Previn leads an all-Strauss concert at which Felicity Lott will sing the ''Four Last Songs'' and James Sommerville will be the soloist in the Horn Concerto. The second half of the program is devoted to the picturesque ''Symphonia Domestica.'' Mr. Frubeck de Burgos returns for the finale on Sunday at 2:30 p.m., a performance of the Beethoven Symphony No. 9. The soloists are Christine Brewer, soprano; Nancy Maultsby, mezzo-soprano; Marcus Haddock, tenor, and Reinhard Hagen, bass. Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass. Tickets: $14 (lawn) to $76 for tonight's concert; $15 (lawn) to $85 for the concerts tomorrow and Sunday; (413) 733-2500 (Kozinn).
Dance

LES BALLETS TROCKADERO DE MONTE CARLO. The lads are back and looking their fabulous tu-tu best. But next week they'll be off to Europe to break new hearts. Highlights of this closing weekend's performances by the all-male ballet troupe include ''Raymonda's Wedding'' (tonight and tomorrow night) and ''Russian Dance'' (tomorrow afternoon) in a repertory that ranges wide, from Merce Cunningham's ''Cross Currents'' to ''Dying Swan.'' Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $38. Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea; (212) 242-0800 (Jennifer Dunning)

BRYANT PARK PRESENTS AUGUST DANCE. This enterprising festival, which closes tonight, will present dances by Cortez & Company Contemporary/Ballet, which presents work by the former Paul Taylor dancer Hernando Cortez that brims with a sense of elusive drama. Peggy Cone and the Central Park Stompers open the show. Tonight at 6. Free. Bryant Park, Avenue of the Americas at 40th Street; (212) 768-4242 (Dunning).

''DANCE AT THE WHITE BARN THEATER.'' Lucille Lortel began to present dance at her White Barn theater in 1949, with performances by Katherine Dunham's company. This exhibition of archival photographs, costumes and memorabilia organized by Lynn Garafola spans a wide range of dance personalities and styles, from ballet and modern to ethnic and Broadway musical theater dance. Through Sept. 3. Fridays through Sundays, 7 to 10 p.m. or by appointment. Free. White Barn Theater, Newtown Turnpike, Westport, Conn.; (203) 227-3768 (Dunning).

DOWNTOWN DANCE FESTIVAL. Battery Park lawn, Lower Manhattan. Presented by the Battery Dance Company, the five-day free festival opens on Sunday for its 19th year with performances by the Vanaver Caravan of American folk dancers and the Incidents Physical Theater, which will present a medieval fairy-tale fantasy by Christina Briggs, Edward Winslow and their gymnastic dancers. Sunday at 2 p.m. (212) 219-3910 (Dunning).

LINCOLN CENTER OUT OF DOORS, Lincoln Center plazas. The free festival careers around the world this weekend, starting this afternoon at 5:30 with the Maximo Damian Scissors Dancers from Peru in pre-Columbian dance and the Harambee Dance Company, which performs African dance and drumming, at 6:45 p.m. Then it is back to Africa on Sunday afternoon, the festival's closing day, with performers from the Maimouna Keita School of African dance at 5 p.m. (212) 875-5108 (Dunning).

NEW YORK INTERNATIONAL FRINGE FESTIVAL AT CHARAS/EL BOHIO. Charas/El Bohio, 605 East Ninth Street, East Village. From Vienna, Vis Plastica creates organic beings out of inorganic matter in ''Perpetuum Mobile -- heart beats and brain waves,'' today at 8:30 p.m., tomorrow at 10:30 p.m. and Sunday at 2 p.m. in the Charas courtyard. From New York City, a budding jazz pianist experiences cultural clashes, polyglot puns and balancing acts in ''Leo on Tour and Back,'' tomorrow at 4:45 p.m., and Sunday at noon and 7 p.m., in the Charas Armando Perez space. From New York City, Loka Maer urges audiences to ''mesmerize your mucked-up mind'' in ''Dream Play,'' tomorrow at 2:15 p.m. and Sunday at 7:15 p.m. in the Charas Bimbo Rivas Performance Space. From Allentown, Pa., Keiko Yamamoto explores the ability to see beyond the shadows in ''Cave Theory,'' tomorrow at 6:15 p.m., Charas Carol Watson Theater. Tickets: $12 for indoor performances; outdoors free. (212) 420-8877 (Dunning).

FRINGE FESTIVAL AT CONTEXT. 28 Avenue A, between Second and Third Streets, East Village. From New York City, Kim Irwin, Jody Oberfelder and an all-female squad and marching band examine cheerleading in ''Wanted: X-Cheerleaders,'' tomorrow at 10:30 p.m. Tickets: $12; (212) 420-8877 (Dunning).

FRINGE FESTIVAL AT THE HENRY STREET SETTLEMENT. 466 Grand Street, at Pitt Street, Lower East Side. Westendopera, from Munich, brings the lives of Munich youth to the stage in a show created and danced by German hip-hoppers in ''Hip-Hopera,'' today at 3:30 p.m., tomorrow at 8:15 p.m. and Sunday at 6:30 p.m. From Vienna, Tanztheater Homunculus explores the abyss behind the lightness of operetta in ''Sommerfrische,'' tonight at 9:30, tomorrow at 6:30 p.m. and Sunday at noon. Tickets: $12; (212) 420-8877 (Dunning).

FRINGE FESTIVAL AT PARADISE. 64 East Fourth Street, East Village. From Linz, Austria, the Cy-ancal Company gets cynical about monotony and apathy, on a sound carpet, in ''With the Clearness Comes the Cold.'' Tonight at 7, tomorrow at 4 p.m. and Sunday at 4:45 p.m. Tickets: $12; (212) 420-8877 (Dunning).

FRINGE FESTIVAL AT PRESENT COMPANY THEATORIUM. 198 Stanton Street, between Ridge and Attorney Streets, Lower East Side. From New York City, the Stratton Gonzalez Dance Theater explores immigrants' contributions to American art and culture in ''A Place in Line.'' Sunday at 5 p.m. Tickets: $12; (212) 420-8877 (Dunning).

FRINGE FESTIVAL AT ROD RODGERS STUDIO. 62 East Fourth Street, between the Bowery and Second Avenue, East Village. From Brooklyn, Abena Appiah-Kubi Koomson unites the worlds of an American-born woman and her Ghanaian father, who told her Fanti stories, in ''Cozi Sa Wala: Magic Words,'' tonight at 9:15. From Seattle, Michi Broman combines audio, video, dance and the spoken word in ''Gretl,'' tomorrow at 1 p.m. From New York City, a highway trash picker and a female deer help audiences to find the turkey in their hearts in ''North Wind/Turkey Timber,'' tomorrow at 8:45 p.m. and Sunday at 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $12; (212) 420-8877 (Dunning).

FRINGE FESTIVAL AT ST. MARK'S STUDIO THEATER. 94 St. Mark's Place, between First Avenue and Avenue A, East Village. From Toronto, Theater Rusticle explores the terrible, sometimes revelatory journey home from work in ''Now the Day Is Over,'' today at 3:30 p.m. and tomorrow at 2 p.m. Tickets: $12; (212) 420-8877 (Dunning).

FRINGE FESTIVAL AT UNIVERSITY SETTLEMENT. 134 Eldridge Street, between Rivington and Delancey Streets, Lower East Side. From Brooklyn, a displaced Indian-American girl and her stuffed lion embark on a journey of monstrous proportions in ''The Babu Show,'' today at 3:30 p.m., tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. and Sunday at 3 p.m. From Salzburg, Austria, the Laroque Dance Company addresses the mechanisms of decay, destruction and decomposition in ''Faktor3x,'' tonight at 7:45 and tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m. From New York City, Tony Silva Dance and Music presents multimedia dance in ''Air Born,'' tonight at 8:45. From New York, the Artichoke Dance Company presents dance theater with a comic, athletic and feminist twist in ''Ho-Down Showdown,'' tonight at 10:15 and tomorrow at noon. From Los Angeles, Vickie Mendoza and her Vicdog3d company present comic multimedia fantasy in ''Three Worse Flowers,'' tomorrow at 5:15 p.m. From Brooklyn, Caroline Jauch & Company presents a European folk tale about a bloody journey in ''The Handless Maiden,'' Sunday at noon. From New Haven, WSA examines translation from inside the collaborative process, with a pinch of Indian classical dance, in ''Translation/2,'' today at 5:45 p.m. and tomorrow at 9:45 p.m. Tickets: $12; 420-8877 (Dunning).

FRINGE FESTIVAL AT WOW CAFE. 59-61 East Fourth Street, between the Bowery and Second Avenue, East Village. From London, Kunsterwerk-Blend moves into a Dadaesque kindergarten to show audiences how every act becomes a cerebral revolver shot in ''Yo-Land.'' Sunday at 1 p.m. Tickets: $12; (212) 420-8877 (Dunning).

JACOB'S PILLOW DANCE FESTIVAL. In the festival's closing performances, Alonso King's feisty and lyrical Lines Contemporary Ballet will perform dances set to tabla music, the tango and Shostakovich at the Ted Shawn Theater. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. and Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $35-40. At the Doris Duke Studio Theater, Noche Flamenca will turn a black-box stage into a smoky Gypsy tavern filled with passionate music and dance. Tonight at 8:15, tomorrow at 5 and 9 p.m. and Sunday at 2 and 5 p.m. Tickets: $16. Free outdoor entertainment on the Inside/Out Stage will be presented by the Angkor Dance Troupe in ancient Cambodian folk dances (tonight at 6:30) and the modernist Irene Hultman (tomorrow at 6:30 p.m.). Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, George Carter Road, Becket, Mass.; (413) 243-0745 (Dunning).
